questions.question_text: An engineer is configuring a custom application detector for HTTP traffic and wants to import a file that was provided by a third party. Which type of files are advanced application detectors created and uploaded as?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The type of detector, Basic or Advanced. Basic application detectors are created in the web interface as a series of fields. Advanced application detectors are created externally and uploaded as custom .lua files.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/firepower/60/configuration/guide/fpmc-config-guide-v60/Application_Detection.html

Selected Answer: B
The correct answer is B. Configure a trust policy for the CEO.

A trust policy is a special type of access control policy that identifies trusted hosts and networks that are exempt from certain intrusion policies. By creating a trust policy for the CEO, the engineer can ensure that traffic coming from the CEO is always allowed, regardless of any other rules or policies that may be in place. This is a more targeted and specific solution than simply changing the intrusion policy or creating a general firewall bypass. NAT policies, while useful for translating IP addresses, do not provide the same level of control over traffic as access control policies.
Answer B is still the most appropriate. Sometimes examiners may use the wrong definition, like probably in this case. It happened before.
A is not appropriate choice too. Connectivity over Security and personal CEO's rule would be perfect solution but we do not have such answer......

Vague question and answer. 
Trust is an ACTION and is NOT a POLICY.

questions.question_text: Network traffic coming from an organization's CEO must never be denied. Which access control policy configuration option should be used if the deployment engineer is not permitted to create a rule to allow all traffic?

choices.D: Create a NAT policy just for the CEO.
choices.B: Configure a trust policy for the CEO.
choices.A: Change the intrusion policy from security to balance.

questions.question_text: An engineer must deploy a Cisco Secure Firewall Threat Defense device. Management wants to examine traffic without requiring network changes that will disrupt end users. Corporate security policy requires the separation of management traffic from data traffic and the use of SSH over Telnet for remote administration. How must the device be deployed to meet these requirements?

choices.B: in routed mode with a bridge virtual interface
choices.C: in transparent mode with a data interface
choices.D: in routed mode with a diagnostic interface
choices.A: in transparent mode with a management interface

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
This is is the typical setup

choices.D: The attacks are not dangerous to the network.
choices.A: All attacks are listed as low until manually recategorized.
choices.C: The host is not within the administrator's environment.
choices.B: The host is not vulnerable to those attacks.

questions.question_text: A network administrator reviews the attack risk report and notices several low-impact attacks. What does this type of attack indicate?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I think it's B
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/firepower/630/configuration/guide/fpmc-config-guide-v63/working_with_intrusion_events.html#:~:text=Table%203.-,Impact%20Levels,-Impact%20Level

Selected Answer: D
It could be B or D, but since it doesn't specifically say anything about hosts, it is likely D.

choices.D: Only distance vector routing protocols are supported.
choices.A: Only link-state routing protocols are supported.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Seems correct

Dynamic routing protocols: You can, however, add static routes for BVIs. You can also allow dynamic routing protocols through the FTD device using an access rule. Non-bridge group interfaces support dynamic routing.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/firepower/623/configuration/guide/fpmc-config-guide-v623/transparent_or_routed_firewall_mode_for_firepower_threat_defense.html

questions.question_text: What is a limitation to consider when running a dynamic routing protocol on a Cisco Secure Firewall Threat Defense device in IRB mode?
